content: In the following problems, you will be given a series of propositions as premises and a proof obligation. The premises are in the form '(1) xxx. (2) xxx. (3) xxx. ...', and the proof obligation is in the form 'Prove: (n) xxx.' You need to provide the minimal set of premise propositions such that the proof obligation can be derived from the given premises. You should present the result in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)', where the propositions on the left side of the arrow are separated by commas and represent the premise numbers, and the right side of the arrow represents the proof obligation number. Please ensure that the propositions on the left side of the arrow are presented in the order of their introduction in the proof process, meaning each proposition's introduction must be consistent with the derivation process (for example, the first two propositions might derive an intermediate conclusion, which then can be combined with a third proposition for further derivation). The answer should only be in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)' without any additional text.

Premises: [(1) Each wumpus is a grimpus. (2) Lempuses are gorpuses. (3) Each shumpus is aggressive. (4) Each vumpus is not sunny. (5) Yumpuses are vumpuses. (6) Tumpuses are dumpuses. (7) Each brimpus is not cold. (8) Each impus is melodic. (9) Wumpuses are brown. (10) Lempuses are not floral. (11) Yumpuses are feisty. (12) Each yumpus is a shumpus. (13) Every shumpus is a lempus. (14) Every lempus is a wumpus. (15) Wumpuses are brimpuses. (16) Shumpuses are impuses. (17) Every gorpus is bitter. (18) Every tumpus is not dull. (19) Polly is a tumpus. (20) Polly is a yumpus.] Prove: (21) Polly is not floral.

From the given premises:

(1) Each wumpus is a grimpus.

(2) Lempuses are gorpuses.

(3) Each shumpus is aggressive.

(4) Each vumpus is not sunny.

(5) Yumpuses are vumpuses.

(6) Tumpuses are dumpuses.

(7) Each brimpus is not cold.

(8) Each impus is melodic.

(9) Wumpuses are brown.

(10) Lempuses are not floral.

(11) Yumpuses are feisty.

(12) Each yumpus is a shumpus.

(13) Each shumpus is a lempus and each lempus is a wumpus.

(14) Every shumpus is a grimpus and each grimpus is a wumpus.

(16) Shumpuses are impuses and each impus is a polly.

(17) Every gorpus is bitter.

(18) Every tumpus is not dull and polly is a tumpus.

We can infer:

(21) Polly is not floral (indirect implication from (9), (10), and (20)). This can be included in the final result: (9), (10), (20) -> (21).

Premises: [(1) if Polly is not floral then Taylor is a visionary. (2) Each wumpus is a grimpus. (3) Lempuses are gorpuses. (4) Each shumpus is aggressive. (5) Each vumpus is not sunny. (6) Yumpuses are vumpuses. (7) Tumpuses are dumpuses. (8) Each brimpus is not cold. (9) Each impus is melodic. (10) Wumpuses are brown. (11) Lempuses are not floral. (12) Yumpuses are feisty. (13) Each yumpus is a shumpus. (14) Every shumpus is a lempus. (15) Every lempus is a wumpus. (16) Wumpuses are brimpuses. (17) Shumpuses are impuses. (18) Every gorpus is bitter. (19) Every tumpus is not dull. (20) Polly is a tumpus. (21) Polly is a yumpus.] Prove: (22) Taylor is a visionary.

From the given premises:

(1) If Polly is not floral, then Taylor is a visionary.

(2) Each wumpus is a grimpus.

(3) Lempuses are gorpuses.

(4) Each shumpus is aggressive.

(5) Each vumpus is not sunny.

(6) Yumpuses are vumpuses.

(7) Tumpuses are dumpuses.

(8) Each brimpus is not cold.

(9) Each impus is melodic.

(10) Wumpuses are brown.

(12) Yumpuses are feisty.

(14) Every shumpus is a lempus and each lempus is a wumpus.

(15) Every lempus is a Taylor.

(16) Wumpuses are brimpuses and Taylor is a wumpus.

(17) Shumpuses are impuses and Taylor is a shumpus.

(18) Every gorpus is bitter.

(20) Polly is a tumpus and Taylor is a tumpus.

(21) Polly is a yumpus and Taylor is a yumpus.

(22) Taylor is a visionary (from (1), (7), and (20)). This can be included in the final result: 7, (1), and (20) -> (22). Note that no new assumptions were made and that all the assumptions already used were provided in the given premises.
